messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: An earthquake is when the ground shakes a lot.
Earthquakes can break buildings and bridges.
But bridges do not often fall down.
This is true for new bridges, especially.
Engineers now make bridges strong in earthquake areas.
They choose strong ground for the bridge.
The ground does not move much in an earthquake.
So the bridge stays up better.

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.7118 is below the required 0.75. The BERTScore of 0.8968 is below the required 0.90.
1. The MeaningBERT score of 0.7118 indicates the paraphrase lost core meaning: original phrase “design bridges in earthquake zones on areas that are much more resistant to movement” was reduced to “They choose strong ground for the bridge,” removing the engineering focus on resistance to movement.
2. The BERTScore of 0.8968 shows loss of key lexical content: "relatively infrequent" and "modern bridges" were simplified to "do not often fall down" and "new bridges," reducing precision.
Suggestion: Restore the phrase “relatively infrequent collapse,” use “modern bridges,” and rephrase “areas that are more resistant to movement” instead of “strong ground” to meet fidelity requirements.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: An earthquake is when the ground shakes a lot.
Earthquakes can damage buildings and bridges.
Luckily, bridge collapse is relatively infrequent.
This is true, especially with modern bridges.
Engineers now design bridges in earthquake zones.
They build them on areas that are much more resistant to movement.

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: CEFR Compliance. Classifier rated B1. The text uses vocabulary above A2 level. Evidence: word earthquake is B1; word damage is B1; word collapse is B2; word relatively is B2. Sentence "Earthquakes can damage buildings and bridges." uses damage. Sentence "Luckily, bridge collapse is relatively infrequent." uses collapse and relatively. Suggestion: Replace earthquake with a simpler description like "when the ground shakes"; replace damage with hurt; replace collapse with fall down; remove relatively; use only A2 approved words.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: 'Earthquake' means the ground shakes a lot.
The shaking can break buildings and bridges.
Luckily, bridges do not fall down often.
This is true, especially for modern bridges.
Engineers design bridges for places where the ground shakes.
They build on ground that does not move much.

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.6865 is below the required 0.75. The rewrite compresses “damage all structures” into “break buildings and bridges,” losing the sense that earthquakes affect every structure.
FAIL: Fidelity Failure. The BERTScore of 0.8994 is below the required 0.90. Key phrase “damage all structures” was replaced by “break,” reducing lexical precision.
Suggestion: Retain the phrase “damage all structures” to preserve full meaning.
Suggestion: Use “damage” instead of “break” for consistency with the original.
Suggestion: Include “including bridges” to reflect the original scope.
Suggestion: Restore “have learned to design” to show that engineers’ methods improved over time.
